title: 103_hr367
content: The curr_chunk is a section header titled "SHORT TITLE." The "Social Security Trust Fund Amendments of 1993" Act establishes a Board of Trustees for the Federal Old-Age and Survivors Insurance Trust Fund and the Federal Disability Insurance Trust Fund, consisting of government officials and public members nominated by the President. The Board of Trustees for the Social Security Trust Fund consists of government officials and public members nominated by the President for four-year terms, subject to Senate confirmation. The Secretary of the Treasury serves as the Managing Trustee, and the Commissioner of Social Security serves as the Board's Secretary. The Board of Trustees for the Social Security Trust Fund, with the Commissioner of Social Security as Secretary, must meet at least ten times a year. Their duties include holding the Trust Funds, reporting annually to Congress on fund operations, notifying Congress if funds are insufficient, and recommending administrative improvements for program coordination. The Board of Trustees for the Social Security Trust Fund meets regularly to oversee the management of the funds, recommend policy changes, and approve investments in the best interest of beneficiaries. Their responsibilities include providing benefits, covering administrative expenses, and acting prudently with diligence. The Managing Trustee is responsible for investing Trust Funds to minimize risks and diversify investments, following specific guidelines outlined in subsection (d). Not more than one-fourth of investments can be in interest-bearing obligations of the United States. The issuance of public-debt obligations for purchase by the Trust Funds is authorized under chapter 31 of title 31. These obligations shall have maturities and interest rates based on market yields of US obligations. The Managing Trustee, with Board approval, invests excess funds in interest-bearing US obligations or guaranteed securities, as well as bonds and securities according to section (c).
